feed.title: Lighting for Architecture
feed.subtitle: An Architectural Lighting firm, based in Athens Greece, working with simplicity in mind.

entry.title: Historical archive Athens 2004
entry.content:
The Historical Archive of the Organising Committee of the ATHENS 2004 Olympic Games, covering the period from the bidding to the completion of the Games.

It is hosted in the premises of the International Olympic Academy in Ancient Olympia in a room of 420 sq. meters and includes rich printed, audiovisual and digitized material as well as official objects of the Athens Olympic Games.

The work of the creation of the Historical Archive of ATHENS 2004 was entirely financed by the donation of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to whom the relevant archival material belongs to, while the materialization was undertaken by the non-profit corporation “Historical Archive ATHENS 2004” which was founded to serve this purpose.

  • Architects: F. & K. Kydoniatis Architects & Partners
  • Construction: Electron Line S.A.

All images courtesy of F. & K. Kydoniatis Architects & Partners. Used under permission.

Historical archive Athens 2004 was originally published by L4A at Lighting for Architecture on November 20, 2014.

entry.title: Grande Bretagne: picture lights refurbishment
entry.content:
Hotel Grande Bretagne is a landmark hotel situated right in the heart of the city of Athens since 1874. Ηundreds of works of art housed in its walls.

L4A took over the refurbishment of the traditional picture lights by replacing the halogen lamps with LED’s with excellent color rendering properties.

  • Customer: Hotel Grande Bretagne
  • Photos: Yannis Koniaris

All images courtesy of Yannis Koniaris. Used under permission.

Grande Bretagne: picture lights refurbishment was originally published by L4A at Lighting for Architecture on November 06, 2014.

entry.title: PwC
entry.content:
PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) is a network of firms in 157 countries with more than 184.000 people, delivering quality in assurance, tax and advisory services.

PwC in Greece is the largest professional services firm in the country, with premises in Athens and Thessaloniki and over 800 employees. The lighting in this open space office was based on visual comfort, limitation of glare and energy saving.

  • Customer: PwC
  • Architect: Design+structureS LTD Takis Yalelis Architect
  • Construction: Ergosteel SA, Vitael SA

All images courtesy of Design+structureS LTD. Used under permission.

PwC was originally published by L4A at Lighting for Architecture on October 29, 2014.

entry.title: L4A lights the new Wind stores
entry.content:
Wind obtains a new face in the retail market presenting its new hi-tech stores characterized by friendliness, interactivity and personalized service.

The design of the new stores (along with the conceptual lighting design) is signed by Allen International. L4A is proud to be Wind’s choice for the implementation and the adaptation of the lighting design to the needs of every store.

L4A lights the new Wind stores was originally published by L4A at Lighting for Architecture on October 16, 2014.

entry.title: One Athens
entry.content:
In the late 1950s, Constantinos Doxiadis, one of the leading figures of modern Greek architecture, was looking for a site to build his new company’s Athens offices. He selected a plot in the pine-clad foothills of Mount Lycabettus, a vantage point that afforded sweeping views of the city as far as the sea.

Divercity architects were inspired by Doxiadis’ philosophy in converting his former headquarters into a 21st century residential complex by the name One Athens. Maintaining the elegant simplicity of the structure, the new design is faithful to the legacy of this landmark, but forward-looking in its cutting-edge design, innovative use of materials, and ability to respond to the modern lifestyle.

L4A continued and completed the lighting development started by Diathlasis SA.

  • Customer (project development): Cyclamino SA
  • Contractor: J&P AVAX
  • Architects: Divercity
    • Head architects: Nikolas Travasaros & Christina Achtypi
    • Design team: Dimitris Travasaros, Dimitra Karampelia, Dimosthenis Lappas, Angelina Manitsa, Marios Triantafyllou
  • Associates architects: Takis Travasaros, Apostolia Kokkini, Sandy Papastauropoulou, Michalis Tsimilis
  • Structural engineering: E.T.E.S.M.E.
  • Electromechanical engineering: EL.T.E.ME.
  • Construction supervision: Nikolas Travasaros, Takis Travasaros, Dimitris Travasaros
  • Acoustic design: Theodore Timagenis & Associates
  • Landscape design: ELANDSCAPE - H. Pangalou & Associates

Photos: Nikos Daniilidis, George Fakaros

One Athens was originally published by L4A at Lighting for Architecture on October 14, 2014.

entry.title: Nikos Koulis Athens
entry.content:
“The first Nikos Koulis Jewels boutique in Athens, located in its posh shopping area in the center of the city, is a product of a constant, evolving intercourse between masculine and feminine elements. The sources of inspiration behind its creation are universal: references to a G. Gershwin melody, a phrase by F. S. Fitzgerald, the decolorized photography of classic films, the electrical vibe of New York, Paris and Shanghai during the 30’s and 40’s.

The result is the creation of an atmospheric space resembling a woman’s boudoir, combined with the mystery of an austere men’s lounge. The dialogue between the eternal game of men-women attraction is reflected in all the design facets: fine grey flannel on the walls, grey, black and dark green marbles, intense metals such as bronze and back iron, display forms made of cement co-existing with art deco curved mirrors, custom-made graceful lighting sconces, velvet and rattan textures. The space as a whole establishes the privacy and proximity, redefining the the position of the client toward his objects of desire - Nikos Koulis fine jewelry.

Designed by the Athens-based Stage Design Office, Stavros Papagiannis & Yorgos Kiriazis, in a close collaboration with the brand owners, Nikos Koulis Jewels boutique exceeds the commercial character of a store, inviting its clients to experience the intimacy of an unconfined, private moment.

Alexandros Papadias designed the marble sconces, the tailor-made vitrine étalage, as well as the bronze door knobs; Michael Anastassiades the satin brass lights, while Cypriot artist Socrates Socratous has created an in-situ installation in the outdoor display, while classic music is played from the outdoor loudspeakers, creating a sensation to visitors and reflecting Nikos Koulis’ intricate philosophy.”

  • Customer: Nikos Koulis
  • Interior Design: Stage Design Office
  • Tailor-made objects: Alexander Papadias
  • Photos: Grey Studio, Panagiotis Baxevanis

All images courtesy of Stage Design Office. Used under permission.

Nikos Koulis Athens was originally published by L4A at Lighting for Architecture on October 07, 2014.

entry.title: On the boards IX
entry.content:
Exterior lighting for a house at Tirana (Albania). Raytraced with Relux.

Its internal port of Radiance (called Vision) seems outdated and slow, but it’s easy to use and reliable. Radiance since 1985 is the most generally useful software package for architectural lighting simulation and often serves as the underlying simulation engine for many other packages.

On the boards IX was originally published by L4A at Lighting for Architecture on September 04, 2014.

entry.title: Competition for the redesign of Katehaki Square
entry.content:
Congratulations to George Batzios and his team for the 2nd prize in the competition for the redesign of Katehaki Square (Chania, Crete).

We are very happy that we assisted in the lighting design. Experts and non experts agree that his proposal deserved the 1st prize.

entry.title: The Greek Pavilion at the 14th Biennale
entry.content:
The Greek participation in the 14th International Architecture Exhibition - La Biennale di Venezia, is directed and curated by the National Commissioner architect and professor Yannis Aesopos, under the title “Tourism Landscapes: Remaking Greece”.

It explores the role of tourism as a vehicle of modernization of Greece through the emergence of constructed tourism landscapes: hotels and resorts, organized beaches, archaeological sites and museums, public space designs and infrastructure facilities. Moreover, it focuses on the concurrent (re)shaping of Greek national identity that is enhanced through the contact of the “other”, the foreign, new and global element, which the activity of tourism presupposes.

  • Customer: Ministry of Environment, Energy & Climate Change
  • Commissioner - Curator: Yannis Aesopos
  • Advisors: Elias Zenghelis, Georgios Panetsos, Lois Papadopoulos
  • Assistants: Maria Chassioti, Ioanna Koulouri, Georgios Kourakos, Mina Roussou, Thodoris Svoronos
  • Press & Communication: Angeliki Evripioti, Anais Evripioti
  • Photographers: Panos Kokkinias, Yiorgis Yerolympos
  • Construction: R.C.TECH

All images courtesy of the organizers. Used under permission.

The Greek Pavilion at the 14th Biennale was originally published by L4A at Lighting for Architecture on June 18, 2014.

entry.title: Nikos Koulis, Mykonos
entry.content:
The source of inspiration behind the design of the first Nikos Koulis Jewels boutique in Mykonos has been the brand logo. Designed by Stage Design Office, Stavros Papayannis & Yorgos Kiriazis, along with the brand owners, this new boutique has become an international sensation. The austere and emblematic logo invokes a religious symbolism and determined the integration of an ascetic aesthetic with multiple references in the cycladic tradition.

The large stone slabs from the near island of Rinia on the floor, the vintage wood door and the arches in the stone walls were preserved and combined with the ethereal cast iron displays and the white marble surfaces, which allow day light to diffuse in the once dark “katogi” (cellar), intensifying the emotional aspect of the jewels’ discovery. The marble counter reminiscing an altar where the “mystery” of showcasing the jewels is being held, combined with the tailor-made pews from the same material, redefine the position of the client toward his object of desire, establishing respect and proximity.

The boutique exterior follows the same intrinsic approach, with a discreet logo and a small suspended display, reflecting Nikos Koulis’ intricate philosophy.

  • Customer: Nikos Koulis
  • Interior Design: Stage Design Office
  • Special Marble Items: Alexander Papadias
  • Electrician: Dimitris Protopapadakis
  • Photos: Grey Studio, Panagiotis Baxevanis

All images courtesy of Stage Design Office. Used under permission.

Nikos Koulis, Mykonos was originally published by L4A at Lighting for Architecture on May 27, 2014.

entry.title: Royal Botania
entry.content:
We are excited to announce the beginning of our exclusive partnership with Royal Botania regarding its Outdoor Lighting Collection.

Royal Botania uses superior natural materials: premium Javanese plantation teak, granite, stainless steel, glass. When placed outside all the Royal Botania lighting models will integrate into their natural environment. Most of the lamps are designed to use energy-saving light bulbs with low energy consumption and LED.

Royal Botania was originally published by L4A at Lighting for Architecture on May 23, 2014.

entry.title: Tourism Landscapes: Remaking Greece
entry.content:
Greece will participate in the 14th International Architecture Exhibition - La Biennale di Venezia (07/06 - 23/11/2014). The Greek participation is directed and curated by the national commissioner, architect and professor Yannis Aesopos, under the title “Tourism Landscapes: Remaking Greece”.

It explores the role of tourism as a vehicle of modernization of Greece through the emergence of constructed tourism landscapes: hotels and resorts, organized beaches, archaeological sites and museums, public space designs and infrastructure facilities. Moreover, it focuses on the concurrent (re)shaping of Greek national identity that is enhanced through the contact of the “other”, the foreign, new and global element, which the activity of tourism presupposes. L4A and iGuzzini are special supporters.

  • website
  • facebook page

Tourism Landscapes: Remaking Greece was originally published by L4A at Lighting for Architecture on May 22, 2014.

entry.title: Athens International Airport, central food court
entry.content:
Athens International Airport “Eleftherios Venizelos”, began operation on 29 March 2001 and is the primary civilian airport that serves the city of Athens and the region of Attica.

It is Greece’s biggest airport and serves as the hub and base of Aegean Airlines and its subsidiary Olympic Air. The airport serves just under 13 million passengers annually.

  • Customer: Athens International Airport
  • Architects: AIA, Fotini Ioannidou
  • Electrical Engineers: AIA, Ilias Tsonos
  • Construction: AGT Construction & Service Group

Photos: Anna Perela

Athens International Airport, central food court was originally published by L4A at Lighting for Architecture on May 19, 2014.
